revised_title: Efficiency of Elements Emitting Soft X-Rays at Higher Voltages
tldr: The authors investigated the efficiency of 14 elements emitting soft X-rays at various voltages up to 6000 volts. They found that the efficiency varied by a factor of about 2 among the elements and was a periodic function of the atomic number. Molybdenum was the most efficient element, and there was a significant change in the efficiency of elements from chromium to copper as the voltage increased. The results provide insights into the behavior of soft X-rays and their relation to ordinary X-rays.
